description.narrative: This project will support official counterparts and civil society partners in advocating for the prompt ratification of the Istanbul Convention

activity-description.narrative: Citizens of Skopje will benefit from the activities

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - social services (incl youth development and women+ children)

1. Number of developed sexual assault centres in the country 2. Number of developed SOPs 3. Data collection framework developed 4. Number of workshops and number of judges and prosecutors trained 5. Number of conferences and number of local governance actors attending

comment.narrative: 1. There are no sexual assault centres in the country in accordance with Article 25 of the Istanbul Convention. 2. There are no SOPs in place for health and multisectoral referral and coordination of SGBV cases. 3. There is no coherent colleciton of data related to violence against women by relevant institutions. 4. The due dilligence concept in SGBV context in accordance with Istanbul Convention and CEDAW recomendations is not well known nor practiced in the legal environment in the country. 5. There is low awareness of the SGBV among actors in the local governance.
1. Assistance provided to state institutions in SACs operations 2. Taking part in drafting the new Law on Violence Against Women

During 2018 continuous assistance and monitoring of the response was provided to varios state institutions in interpretation of the SOPs and proper operations of the three SACs. During that time 4 victims of sexual violence were assisted through the procedures in a way that protects them from revictimisation and helps them maintain dignity. Furthermore, our gender specialist took part in the working group on the new Law on VAW. The draft law has been submitted to the Parliament for adoption.
1. Assistance provided to state institutions in SACs operations 2. Taking part in drafting the new Law on Violence Against Women

During 2018 continuous assistance and monitoring of the response was provided to varios state institutions in interpretation of the SOPs and proper operations of the three SACs. During that time 4 victims of sexual violence were assisted through the procedures in a way that protects them from revictimisation and helps them maintain dignity. Furthermore, our gender specialist took part in the working group on the new Law on VAW. The draft law has been submitted to the Parliament for adoption.

1. Three sexual assault centres are developed and equiped. 2. SOPs for health and multisectoral referral and coordination of SGBV cases are developed. 3. Data collection framework is created and capacities of country’s authorities in data collection are strenghtened. 4. Two workshops on due dilligence are held and at least 40 judges and prosecutors are trained. 5. Two conferences for women in politics on a local level are held and at least 70 women actors on a local level attended both.

In coordination with the Ministry of Health and other UN agencies three locations have been identified as most optimal and three sexual assault centres have been developed and properly equiped in Skopje, Kumanovo and Tetovo. The SACs were designed as one-stop location where female and male victims of rape and serious sexual assault can receive medical care and advice, and have the opportunity to assist the police investigation, including undergoing a forensic examination. The SOP's will consolidate the professional practice of police, judicial, forensic and sexual assault services in responding effectively and appropriately to the needs of victim/survivors.
In order to strenghten the capacities in data collection of the national authorities a data collection framework has been developed that sets out a minimum common data categories required for collecting comprehensive public data on violence against women and domestic violence in the country. and defines the required data systems that need to be set-up by public authorities such as the judiciary, the police and social welfare services.
During the project course, two expert workshops have been organised to raise the importance of the due diligence principle in the context of violence against women and domestic violence in combination with other human rights principles. During the workshops a total of 43 judges and public prosecutors from all four appelatte areas - Bitola, Skopje, Gostivar and Stip. They have been trained to more effectively deal with victims or perpetrators of all acts of violence covered by the scope of this Convention, on the prevention and detection of such violence, equality between women and men, the needs and rights of victims, as well as on how to prevent secondary victimisation.
Also, to provide support to development of leadership skills of women in politics to drive and expand the VAW agenda to the local level of government, three conferences have been organised that have been attended by an average of 90 women from all political parties in the country active on a local level. These meetings will help enable development of these women skills as active politicians to consolidate political will and commitment of all parties to create an inclusive society that recognize the need to promote gender equality.
